clean_content:
Definition / general

* Indeterminate cell histiocytosis is an extremely rare neoplastic proliferation of cells of dendritic / histiocytic lineage that share immunophenotypic features of Langerhans cells but lack Birbeck granules and langerin expression

Essential features

* Skin involvement can be solitary or multifocal* Usually restricted to skin, with rare organ or lymph node involvement* Indeterminate cells are histopathologically and antigenically similar to Langerhans cells but lack Birbeck granules and langerin (CD207) expression* Clinical course varies: spontaneous regression, stable disease, rapid progression or recurrence

Terminology

* Indeterminate cell histiocytosis* Indeterminate cell tumor* Indeterminate dendritic cell tumor

ICD coding

* ICD-10: [D76.3](https://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/D50-D89/D70-D77/D76-/D76.3) - other histiocytosis syndromes

Epidemiology

* Rare neoplasm, with 85 cases reported between 1985 - 2016 ([Am J Dermatopathol 2018;40:736](29877893))* Reported in all age groups, with a median age of 45* Near equal M:F

Sites

* Cutaneous involvement (88%) is most common ([Am J Dermatopathol 2018;40:736](29877893))* Lymph node (9%) and spleen (2.3%) involvement less common ([Am J Dermatopathol 2018;40:736](29877893))

Etiology

* Etiology remains uncertain* Multiple hypotheses on the relationship between indeterminate cells and Langerhans cells, including:
    + Indeterminate cells are Langerhans cells that have lost their Birbeck granules+ Indeterminate cells are immature Langerhans cells* A subset of cases express dendritic cell marker ZBTB46, raising the possibility that a subset of cases arise directly from bone marrow progenitors as opposed to embryonic precursors that locally renew in the skin ([Mod Pathol 2018;31:1479](29743654))* Association between other hematologic neoplasms has been reported (including B cell lymphoma, T cell lymphoma, acute myeloid leukemia and chronic myelomonocytic leukemia) ([Am J Surg Pathol 2008;32:1868](18813122), [J Cutan Pathol 2017;44:958](28880462), [Am J Dermatopathol 2019;41:461](30024412), [Dermatol Res Pract 2010;2010:569345](20672000))* Indeterminate cell histiocytosis can share clonal abnormality of associated lymphoma or leukemia ([Am J Surg Pathol 2008;32:1868](18813122))

Clinical features

* Reported in all age groups, with a median age of 45* Near equal M:F patients* Single cutaneous papulonodule or multiple lesions (few to innumerable)* Can have plaques and tumors with leonine facies ([J Cutan Pathol 2016;43:158](26272726))* Usually restricted to skin with rare organ or lymph node involvement* Clinical course varies: spontaneous regression, stable disease, rapid progression or recurrence* Reference: [Am J Dermatopathol 2018;40:736](29877893)

Diagnosis

* Skin biopsy for localized lesions* Systemic workup to exclude deep involvement* CT scans and bone marrow biopsy

Laboratory

* Can have elevated lactate dehydrogenase, erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C reactive protein ([Serbian J Dermatology Venereol 2018;10:18](https://doi.org/10.2478/sjdv-2018-0004))

Radiology description

* True cutaneous indeterminate cell histiocytosis typically lacks evidence of deep organ involvement on imaging

Prognostic factors

* Cases restricted to the skin typically behave indolently* Involvement of deep or visceral tissues or bone marrow may portend worse prognosis

Case reports

* 6 year old girl with polypoid and verrucoid lesions of the vulva ([Am J Dermatopathol 2018;40:736](29877893))* 13 year old girl with pityriasis rosea type rash ([Acta Derm Venereol 2002;82:288](12361135))* 28 year old man presented after a mosquito bite ([Medicine (Baltimore) 2015;94:e1443](26313805))* 48 year old woman with a later diagnosis of mycosis fungoides ([Am J Dermatopathol 2019;41:461](30024412))* 55 year old woman with a history of burning and confluent erythematous papules on the face and arms ([Cureus 2021;13:e12850](33628700))* 55 year old woman presented with leonine facies ([J Cutan Pathol 2016;43:158](26272726))* 55 year old man with complete response to ultraviolet phototherapy ([J Cutan Pathol 2017;44:958](28880462))* 61 year old man with recurrence after excision ([J Pathol Transl Med 2018;52:243](29621879))* 72 year old man with chronic myelomonocytic leukemia ([J Cutan Pathol 2017;44:958](28880462))* 74 year old woman with a prior history of follicular lymphoma demonstrating t(14;18) translocation ([Am J Surg Pathol 2008;32:1868](18813122))* 90 year old man with aggressive case mimicking angiosarcoma ([Ann Dermatol 2017;29:614](28966519))

Treatment

* Surgical excision for isolated lesions* Psoralen and ultraviolet A therapy (PUVA) ([J Cutan Pathol 2017;44:958](28880462), [Autops Case Rep 2016;6:33](27547741), [Kaohsiung J Med Sci 2004;20:24](15481563))* Chemotherapy can be considered for more aggressive disease or those cases associated with concurrent myeloid or lymphoid neoplasm

Clinical images

Images hosted on other servers:  

[![Erythematous papules on face and neck](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/lymphnodesindeterminatecelltumorspmc02.jpg)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/33628700/#&gid=article-figures&pid=figure-1-uid-0)

Erythematous papules on face and neck

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/lymphnodesindeterminatecelltumorspmc03.jpg)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26265687/#&gid=article-figures&pid=fig-1-uid-0)

Ill defined, erythematous subcutaneous nodule

Microscopic (histologic) description

* Dermal infiltration by pale eosinophilic histiocytic cells with reniform nuclei* Background reactive lymphocytes* Scant to absent eosinophils* Can have multinucleated cells* Spindled morphology is less common* References: [Am J Dermatopathol 2018;40:736](29877893), [Blood 2015;126:2344](26438513), [Arch Pathol Lab Med 2003;127:748](12741905), [Am J Surg Pathol 2008;32:1868](18813122), [Cureus 2021;13:e12850](33628700)

Microscopic (histologic) images

Contributed by Ryanne A. Brown, M.D., M.B.A.  

[![dermal histiocytoid cells](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/lymphnodesindeterminatecelltumorsbrown01.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/lymphnodesindeterminatecelltumorsbrown01.jpg)

Dermal histiocytoid cells

[![histiocytoid cells](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/lymphnodesindeterminatecelltumorsbrown02.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/lymphnodesindeterminatecelltumorsbrown02.jpg)

Histiocytoid cells

[![CD68](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/lymphnodesindeterminatecelltumorsbrown03.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/lymphnodesindeterminatecelltumorsbrown03.jpg)

CD68

[![CD1a](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/lymphnodesindeterminatecelltumorsbrown04.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/lymphnodesindeterminatecelltumorsbrown04.jpg)

CD1a

  

[![S100](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/lymphnodesindeterminatecelltumorsbrown05.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/lymphnodesindeterminatecelltumorsbrown05.jpg)

S100

[![Langerin](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/lymphnodesindeterminatecelltumorsbrown06.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/lymphnodesindeterminatecelltumorsbrown06.jpg)

Langerin

[![BRAF V600E](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/lymphnodesindeterminatecelltumorsbrown07.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/lymphnodesindeterminatecelltumorsbrown07.jpg)

BRAF V600E

Positive stains

* Positive for [S100](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainss100.html), [CD1a](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd1a.html), [CD68](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd68.html)* Variably express [CD4](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd4.html), [CD45](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd45.html), [CD56](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd56.html), [lysozyme](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainslysozyme.html)* References: [Am J Dermatopathol 2018;40:736](29877893), [Blood 2015;126:2344](26438513), [Arch Pathol Lab Med 2003;127:748](12741905), [Am J Surg Pathol 2008;32:1868](18813122)

Negative stains

* Negative for [langerin (CD207)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd200.html#cd207)* Negative for histiocytic marker [CD163](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd163.html)* B cell and T cell markers, follicular dendritic cell markers ([CD21](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd21.html), [CD23](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd23.html) and [CD35](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd30to39.html#cd35)), [CD30](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd30.html) and [MPO](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsmyeloperoxidase.html)* References: [Am J Dermatopathol 2018;40:736](29877893), [Blood 2015;126:2344](26438513), [Arch Pathol Lab Med 2003;127:748](12741905), [Am J Surg Pathol 2008;32:1868](18813122)

Flow cytometry description

* No known abnormalities in peripheral blood flow cytometry in true cutaneous indeterminate cell histiocytosis* For flow cytometry information for cases of chronic myelomonocytic leukemia with an indeterminate cell-like immunophenotype, please refer to [chronic myelomonocytic leukemia](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/myeloproliferativecmml.html)

Electron microscopy description

* Histiocytic cells show nuclear infoldings with peripheral villi ([Rare Tumors 2013;5:e13](23772299))* Lamellated dense bodies but no Birbeck granules ([Acta Derm Venereol 2002;82:288](12361135))

Electron microscopy images

Contributed by Ryanne A. Brown, M.D., M.B.A.  

[![No Birbeck granules](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/lymphnodesindeterminatecelltumorsbrown08.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/lymphnodesindeterminatecelltumorsbrown08.jpg)

No Birbeck granules

Molecular / cytogenetics description

* *ETV3::NCOA2* in a subset ([Blood 2015;126:2344](26438513), [BMJ Case Rep 2017;2017:bcr2017221538](29070620))* *BRAF* V600E in rare cases ([Ann Diagn Pathol 2015;19:113](25787243), [Virchows Arch 2017;471:467](28695297))* Can share clonal abnormality of associated lymphoma or leukemia ([Am J Surg Pathol 2008;32:1868](18813122))* *TP53* in 1 case ([Leukemia 2022;36:573](34611301))

Sample pathology report

* Skin, left arm, biopsy:
  + Compatible with indeterminate cell histiocytosis (see comment)+ Comment: The presence of histiocytes that express CD1a without langerin is compatible with a diagnosis of indeterminate cell histiocytosis (ICH). The definitive etiology of ICH is not known. ICH may represent a distinct entity, as suggested by the detection of *ETV3::NCOA2* in a subset of cases or a variant of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) that has lost its Birbeck granules ([Blood 2015;126:2344](26438513)). Furthermore, chronic myelomonocytic leukemia (CMML) presenting with skin lesions rarely may mimic the immunohistochemical phenotype of ICH ([J Cutan Pathol 2017;44:1075](28885734)). If clinically indicated, correlation with genomic sequencing to assess for molecular aberrancies characteristic of ICH, LCH or CMML is recommended.+ Microscopic description: The histologic sections show skin with a nodular infiltrate of epithelioid cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, vesicular and variably reniform nuclei and prominent nucleoli present in sheets in the superficial and mid-dermis. On immunohistochemical staining, the lesional cells are positive for CD1a, S100 and CD68 and are negative for langerin, MPO and BRAF V600E.

Differential diagnosis

* [Langerhans cell histiocytosis](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodesLCH.html):
  + [CD1a](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd1a.html)+, [langerin (CD207)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd200.html#cd207)+ (100%), [S100](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainss100.html)+, [CD68](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd68.html)+, [BRAF VE1](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsbraf.html) (~50%)* [Juvenile xanthogranuloma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/skintumornonmelanocyticjuvenilexantho.html):
    + [CD1a](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd1a.html)-, [langerin (CD207)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd200.html#cd207)-, [S100](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainss100.html) variable, [CD68](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd68.html)+* [Multicentric reticulohistiocytosis](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/skintumormultireticulo.html):
      + [CD1a](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd1a.html)-, [langerin (CD207)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd200.html#cd207)-, [S100](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainss100.html) variable, [CD68](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd68.html)+* [Interdigitating dendritic cell sarcomas](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodesinterdigitatingreticulum.html):
        + [CD1a](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd1a.html)-, [langerin (CD207)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd200.html#cd207)-, [S100](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainss100.html)+, [SOX10](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainssox10.html)+* [Histiocytic sarcoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodeshistiocyticsarcoma.html):
          + Significant cytologic atypia, [CD1a](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd1a.html)-* [Chronic myelomonocytic leukemia](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/myeloproliferativecmml.html) secondarily involving the skin:
            + Can have identical morphologic and immunohistochemical findings, correlate with molecular studies ([J Cutan Pathol 2017;44:1075](28885734))* **Reactive indeterminate cell infiltrates**:
              + [Tick bite](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/parasitologytickhyalomma.html) ([Pediatr Dermatol 2017;34:e347](28940363))+ [Scabies](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/skinnontumorscabies.html) ([J Dermatol 2000;27:181](10774146))
